original_data.question: A 76-year-old man is brought to his physician's office by his wife due to progressively worsening hearing loss. The patient reports that he noticed a decrease in his hearing approximately 10 years ago. His wife says that he watches television at an elevated volume and appears to have trouble understanding what is being said to him, especially when there is background noise. He states that he also experiences constant ear ringing and episodes of unsteadiness. On physical examination, the outer ears are normal and otoscopic findings are unremarkable. The patient is unable to repeat the sentence said to him on whisper testing. When a vibrating tuning fork is placed in the middle of the patient's forehead, it is heard equally on both ears. When the vibrating tuning fork is placed by the ear and then on the mastoid process, air conduction is greater than bone conduction. Which of the following structures is most likely impaired in this patient?

model_response:
The patient's inability to repeat a whispered sentence indicates conductive hearing loss. The fact that air conduction is greater than bone conduction indicates that the cochlea is functioning normally. The middle ear transmits sound from the external ear to the inner ear by way of the tympanic membrane, ossicles (malleus, incus, and stapes), and oval window. Conductive hearing loss occurs when sound transmission by the external and middle ear is impaired. This can occur with trauma, infection, or inflammation of the tympanic membrane or middle ear or by fixation of the ossicles (otosclerosis).

The inner ear transmits sound vibrations to the vestibular system by way of the cochlea. Sensorineural hearing loss occurs when cochlear function is impaired. This can occur with trauma, infection, or inflammation of the inner ear or by degeneration of the cochlea (presbycusis). Presbycusis is the most common cause of sensorineural hearing loss in the elderly.

The internal ear also contains the vestibular system, which is responsible for the maintenance of equilibrium. The symptoms of vestibular dysfunction include dizziness, vertigo, and imbalance.

Given the patient's age and the long-standing nature of his symptoms, presbycusis is the most likely cause of his hearing loss. Presbycusis is a degenerative condition that affects the cochlea and is associated with aging. It is a sensorineural hearing loss that is usually bilateral and symmetric.

###Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
The expected function of a member of the medical profession.
A female partner in marriage.
A general term for the complete loss of the ability to hear from both ears.

An indication that the patient provides information about their vital signs, status, or subjective feelings. Some systems also consider information reported by the patient's family or guardian as patient-reported.
Made less in size or amount or degree.
The ability or act of sensing and transducing ACOUSTIC STIMULATION to the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM. It is also called audition.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
A female partner in marriage.
A solid composed of an impermeable occlusive backing and a formulation matrix in which the active and/or inert ingredient(s) are dissolved or dispersed; possibly includes an adhesive layer.

The transmission and reproduction of transient images of fixed or moving objects. An electronic system of transmitting such images together with sound over a wire or through space by apparatus that converts light and sound into electrical waves and reconverts them into visible light rays and audible sound. (From Webster, 3rd ed)
An elevated level or position or degree; greater than normal in degree or intensity or amount.
The amount of three dimensional space occupied by an object or the capacity of a space or container.
Existing conditions, especially those that would be confused with the phenomenon to be observed or measured.
Any sound which is unwanted or interferes with HEARING other sounds.
A constituent administrative district of a nation.
The accumulation of knowledge or skill that results from direct participation in events or activities.
Continually recurring or continuing without interruption.
Doughnut-shaped object or surface generated by rotating a circle around an axis that does not intersect the circle; any object that resembles a ring.
A noteworthy happening that is distinctive in a series of related events.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
The outer part of the hearing system of the body. It includes the shell-like EAR AURICLE which collects sound, and the EXTERNAL EAR CANAL, the TYMPANIC MEMBRANE, and the EXTERNAL EAR CARTILAGES.
In pathology, a term that is used to describe a tissue specimen that has a normal appearance.

Instruments designed to inspect or auscultate the ear. They are designed primarily to examine the outer ear canal and tympanic membrane by means of light and air under moderate pressure, as with a pneumatic otoscope. (UMDNS, 1999)
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
A set of words that is complete in itself, conveying a statement, question, exclamation, or command and typically containing an explicit or implied subject and a predicate containing a finite verb.
A procedure for critical evaluation; a means of determining the presence, quality, or truth of something.
A tuning fork is a mechanical device which resonates at a given frequency and is used to diagnose hearing disorders and to test for vibratory sense.
An intermediate part or section; an area that is approximately central within some larger region.
A condition in which a person partially loses the ability to hear sounds in one or both ears.

The hearing and equilibrium system of the body. It consists of three parts: the EXTERNAL EAR, the MIDDLE EAR, and the INNER EAR. Sound waves are transmitted through this organ where vibration is transduced to nerve signals that pass through the ACOUSTIC NERVE to the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM. The inner ear also contains the vestibular organ that maintains equilibrium by transducing signals to the VESTIBULAR NERVE.
A tuning fork is a mechanical device which resonates at a given frequency and is used to diagnose hearing disorders and to test for vibratory sense.

The hearing and equilibrium system of the body. It consists of three parts: the EXTERNAL EAR, the MIDDLE EAR, and the INNER EAR. Sound waves are transmitted through this organ where vibration is transduced to nerve signals that pass through the ACOUSTIC NERVE to the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM. The inner ear also contains the vestibular organ that maintains equilibrium by transducing signals to the VESTIBULAR NERVE.
The posterior part of the temporal bone. It is a projection of the petrous bone.

Transmission of sound waves through vibration of bones in the SKULL to the inner ear (COCHLEA). By using bone conduction stimulation and by bypassing any OUTER EAR or MIDDLE EAR abnormalities, hearing thresholds of the cochlea can be determined. Bone conduction hearing differs from normal hearing which is based on air conduction stimulation via the EAR CANAL and the TYMPANIC MEMBRANE.
The components and their relationship and manner of arrangement in constituting a whole.
Loss or abnormality of psychological, physiological, or anatomic structure or function.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
